Ok, I am in minute 3:50 and I already know what's going on. They are talking of 2 different things. The path of a droplet of water is not the line that will be captured in the picture which is no path at all but the simultaneous positions of a succession of DIFFERENT droplets of water that left the spout at different times and in different positions. In steady laminar-flow both shapes are the same because the parcels of fluid in one line of flow follow each other through the same line of flow, so the position of a "train" of parcels matches the path taken by any of the parcels in the same way as the picture of a train moving along a curved track will have a shape that matches the shape of the track itself. But this is not what is going on here where different droplets are not following the same track. and there is no train of droplets following each other.

Another way of interpreting the perceived flying in front of the nozzle is with the radius r and angular velocity w and sideways velocity vs: (w=vs/r)
If the nozzle is pointed outwards the radius of rotation increases and with the same sideways velocity the angular velocity is smaller, so the water laggs behind.
The same applies with the nozzle inward: the radius decreases and with the same sideways velocity the angular velocity increases and the water is in front.

Okay, the disagreement in terms here is due to not fully establishing the frame of reference that you're referring to when tracking the motion of the water particles.

Destin is considering the motion of a droplet of water from a fixed frame of reference. If you follow a drop of water as it is released from the spigot in exactly the 6 o'clock position (for a counter-clockwise rotation) the droplet will land say, somewhere between 5 and 4 o'clock, so it will be "ahead" of where it was released.

Steve is considering the problem with respect to an inertial frame of reference, which he's trying to allude to by saying "snapshot" but is simply failing to use sufficiently technical terminology. In this scenario, the frame of reference rotates with the spigots, so they're essentially fixed, even though they're imparting angular momentum to the water droplets. Watch the "straight line" trajectory of the water droplet at 5:18, and keep in mind which spigot it was released from. At 5:23, that droplet is "ahead" of its release point, but it is well behind the spigot that it was released from, because the angular velocity at the end of the spigot is greater than the sum velocity vector of the droplet of water, (which, after it has been released from the spigot, technically has zero angular velocity.) Thus from an inertial frame of reference, the droplet is trailing the spigot, (and in a snapshot this is clearly illustrated by the stream of droplets, because the further they get from the spigot, the more they have lagged behind its rotation.)

Frame of reference is always necessary to establish, (it simply happens to be "assumed" in many contexts,) when attempting to accurately model the motion of objects. Even the "fixed" frame of reference in Destin's case is actually moving with respect to the movement of Earth through space (along with the rotation of the surface of the Earth, since that's where the experiment is taking place.) So, both answers are correct, but both experimenters fail at basic scientific practice for not having clearly outlined the conditions of the experiment, (How to write lab papers 101 people, c'mon.)

First Sprinkler: Once the water leaves the spout there is no Coreolis force to accelerate it tangentially that’s why it lags behind the sprinkler arms as it moves radially outward. Each particle has the same tangential velocity as it had when it left the nozzle. The drops would have to accelerate tangentially (via Coreolis force) to keep up with the arm as the drops move away from the centre of rotation. Once the drops leave the nozzles they travel in straight lines.
Second sprinkler. This is the exact opposite of the first case.
The flow appears to lead the arms because the water has the tangential velocity that it had when it left the nozzle. There is no Coreolis force to slow the water’s tangential velocity to match the arms. Since the tangential velocity at the nozzle is bigger than nearer the axis the water leads the arms.

1. The first water jet seemed to be lagging because, it was going outward, any object which is further away from center has more centrifugal force. 2. In the second case its angular velocity remained same like the last time, but its distance from center is less so its angular velocity is more than the point of the tube which has the same distance from the center. And it seemed leading .

7:54 If you increase the rotation speed of the "reverse sprinkler" the curvature you see the water making will flip and start to lag behind instead of being in front of the direction of rotation. Not only that but instead of a parabola curving out of the circle it will be curving in like a spiral.

You see that parabola curving out in front of the direction of rotation because the water of moving faster than that "reverse sprinkler" direction of rotation. Be aware that the water inside those tubes are experiencing centrifugal effect and because of that the faster you spin the "reverse sprinkler" the faster the water will want to get out of the tubes so you may need to add a flow restriction to make the effect easier to produce.

Is this a visual representation of phase shift? Because the whole apparatus is rotating in a circle, the vector of the water droplets as they exit the spout follow a wave function, which is shown by the stream of water “drawn” into our fixed frame of reference. The change of spout position acts as a phase shift, changing the direction of the droplet vector at the same location within our frame of reference, though NOT changing the behavior of the function. The rotation speed of the spout changes the period of the function (the curves get tighter as he speeds up rotation) while the water velocity would change the amplitude (not shown since we have constant water velocity).

1. If the tip points out, the drop will keep the same tangential velocity but as far it gets from the center, its angular velocity will decrease (same tangential velocity, grater radius), making the ilussion of trailing behind.

2. If the tip points inside, the drop will keep the same tangential velocity but as near it gets from the center, its angular velocity will increase (same tangential velocity, shorter radius), making the ilussion of being ahead of the tube tip.

This is how the Coriolis Affect works.  Spinning it in the same direction, regardless of flow, left, right, in, or out, it will always curve right(Snap shot).  Spin it in the opposite direction and it will curve left, aka being in the other hemisphere.
but the particles is slowed while the spouts keep moving

The water coming out is making it more distant from the center.  The more outside it gets the faster it has to travel to keep its current pace.  It has no ability to gain any velocity to meet this requirement, so it lags behind.  Then when it shoots inward it has less distance to travel with pretty much the same velocity so it is outpacing the water towards the spout that needs to travel further at the same velocity

This is how I think of this problem: For the first case where the pipes were spurting out the water outwards (away from the center), I think the "real" illusion there was the distance between the end of the pipe and some droplet always increases since the pipe is moving away from it.  On the other hand, when the water was being spurted inwards (towards the center), the distance instead decreases, giving the apparent illusion.  It will be easier to understand what I just said if you imagine it from the pipe's perspective.

The reason it leads the pipe is because the water droplet has the same linear velocity as the tip of the pipe (sidewards component lol) but it also moves toward the center which means the radius decreases and the linear velocity remains the same which leads to an increase in angular velocity compared to the tip of the pipe.
In the normal sprinkler model, the droplet is moving away from the center, radius increases, linear velocity remains the same which means the angular velocity decreases compared to the tip of the pipe, so the droplets are trailing behind the pipe.

To explain the first and the second more unintuitive experiment you can use the construct of coriolis force, which acts on mass that moves relatively to a rotating reference system (sprinkler).

To understand the second experiment in an absolute reference frame. You need to consider the change of the radius a moving water particle goes through. While the water particle almost keeps its tangent velocity (low friction), the metal pipes tangent velocity decreases with the radius decrease. (v=w*r) This behaviour makes the pipe seem slower than the water in the second experiment.

As a physic/math student, the result is nothing surprising, but still the experiments are always nice to see in action.

If I remember correctly, when I was learning general relativity, a very first step concept strike was how you view the difference between acceleration and gravity. And the answer is, if you are in a “uniform” gravity field, there’s no way the observer can distinguish between acceleration and gravity. There’s many examples that you can understand this without problem: accelerating elevator, accelerating vehicles, in which cases, observers experience change of gravity in direction/magnitude, and proves observers cannot tell the difference. One abnormal example is, accelerating box in space (without gravity), in which case observers will just feel like standing still as on earth.

And here comes the interesting one, the rotational frame. In a rotational system, the observers moving along system experiences gravity as well, but the acceleration is not uniform and is proportional to the distance to the center of rotation. This concept is even feature in an anime as an artificial gravity field created on space ship years ago. In the other words, for the case in this video, if you edit the footage so that the camera is following the sprinklers, then those water will subject to the effective gravity and fall outward. That’s the effort I would like to see as addition.

Just add in few details for anyone interested. The effective gravity is proportional to ω*r (if I remember it correctly), ω is the angular velocity, r is distance to the center, and ω=ω(t) is a function of time if the rotation is not uniform. Second, if you observe along sprinklers, you will see that the water is shooting to the left or right, that’s because the initial velocity of water depends on ω, which could have positive sign and negative sign, and therefore water can have different direction.

My guess as to why it's so confusing to predict has to do with how we're generally introduced to Newton's laws. They're only valid in an inertial reference frame, which is usually discussed but quickly forgotten as we get bogged down by problem solving. I know that considering the reference frame is rarely at top of mind for me.

The way the argument was framed, in terms of motion of the water relative to sprinkler arms, should have set off our spidey senses because it would imply we're looking at a non-inertial reference frame and have to either think about motion of water and sprinkler with respect to ground, or introduce corriolis and centrifugal forces (the former of which is not intuitive).

Anyways, thanks for reminding me that step zero in motion analysis is to always frame the problem correctly, both in a literal and figurative sense!

Gah, my comment got removed. But Smarter is incorrect on the first. The vector direction is correct, but Smarter fails to think about the fact that as distance from muzzle increases - there is no additional energy or speed added... it almost is like he is thinking of centrifugal forces as they are further away from the center, still within the system.. Then, yes.. the outside is faster than the inside. With a long enough pipe or simple thing, you would see that pattern as materials bend. But the stuff coming out will be affected by air particles and slow down so that vector which was moving in the direction of motion for the spin, and another straight out for the flow of water.. If we treat them separate, it is super easy to see that the jet will never be faster than the spinning piece after ejection. It will spew outward in a parabola and get slowed down that way. It will also slow down from moving in the direction of the spin, so you end up with a \ points visual effect instead of /. ie: it looks like it is curving back and that is because older water has slowed enough to hit the ground and is further from where the new water is ejected. If you play the thought experiment, or even a slow video you can see the bit that lands on the ground will continue around like it is following the water. edit: and you said the same thing... illusion, vectors, and all.


As for the other - either it'll look like a tornado... or something like that. What's being discussed here in the first example is a matter of streaklines vs pathlines. A streakline is a line drawn through all particles that have passed a certain point in the past (the trailing appearance of the water forms the streakline of all particles that have left the spout). A pathline is the path that any given particle takes (in this case, the pathlines are the linear paths taken by each particle of water after having left the spout).
Wouldn't the rotation of the earth make a difference? Clockwise vs counter rotation of the spin?

I think your debate regarding "trailing" versus "leading" is kind of subjective. You make a very clear case for the direction of motion to be "leading" the nozzles, but the particles as you showed are travelling in straight lines. All things being equal, those particles decelerate the second they leave the nozzle because they no longer have rotational energy being applied to them. If the water pressure pushing the particle out at a given velocity is also the same force rotating the nozzles at the same velocity, I think if you measured the linear distance covered (using pi for the nozzle) you'd find the nozzle traveled farther during any given time frame. If true, then the nozzle is travelling at a higher velocity than the particle once it leaves the nozzle, and the particle could never lead the nozzle. Kind of like dropping a baseball out of the window of a moving car, the baseball can never pass the car. You just have the car driving in a circle.

I think it's easiest to understand from a rotating perspective, where the water stream is curved by both centrifugal and coriolis forces. Centrifugal force is intuitive enough... it just pushes the stream away from the center of rotation. The coriolis force, however, is what makes the stream lead or trail the spout in the rotating reference frame. Because the coriolis force is proportional to velocity, if the velocity is reversed between the outward and inward facing cases, then the leading/trailing phenomenon must be reversed as well.

So I figured out the explanation based off something I first read in Calvin and Hobbes as a kid that I thought was pretty interesting. Basically when you have a spinning disk, the farther out from the center you go the faster the disk is spinning. If you think about it, going farther from the center increases the circumference and thereby the distance to complete a full rotation. So in order to complete the full rotation in the same time as a location closer to the center it has to rotate faster. When the water is shot in towards the center it just has a shorter distance to travel

The solution to really understanding this problem is angular velocity vs velocity.
Once the water leaves the nozzle, it has a fixed velocity.
If it enters on the inside of the "spinning circle" it sort of overtakes the nozzle, because now that circumference is smaller.
If it enters on the outside of said circle, it would have to move faster (as of its velocity on the "stationary" frame of reference) to keep up with the nozzle.
Therefore gives that lagging picture.

Please correct me if I am wrong, though I naively think there is an easier way to figure out the correct answer: Consider a drop of water, after leaving the pipe, since there is almost no force in the plane of rotation, it maintains its angular momentum. Therefore, when it "flies" away from the "rotation" center, the angular speed goes down, thus "lagging" behind. When it "flies" towards the "rotation" center, the angular speed will go up, thus "running" in front.
The second case is a good demonstration of the Coriolis effect.

That's simply coriolis force. To get the idea, imagine yourself located in the center of a rotating circular platform at uniform angular velocity. As you start to walk away from the center and towards the radial direction, your speed is increasing, which means a net external force must be acting on you. To put simply, you're moving from a slower location to a faster location, and as you move, you will seem to be lagging behind than the things surrounding you, since they are in a location which has a greater linear velocity. 4:06

I have been reading some comments on here about conservation of angular momentum and that being the reason why the droplets seems to lead the spout/spray/nozzle. But I am thinking of it totally differently and I'd love to hear if I'm wrong.
Think of it like putting Destin's main point into practise.


When a droplet leaves the spout it's velocity will be a combination of hubwards (to borrow a Terry Prachett term) and the direction of rotation. Now imagine the droplet leaving the spout. If the spout stopped immediately the direction of travel for the droplet would be on the same side of the centre as the spout was heading, i.e. for the counterclockwise (CCW) in the video, it would drift to the right. But that droplet is not influenced by angular momentum anymore because it's not spinning now - it's just heading in the direction it had before. The force on it is simply air resistance and gravity.


So why does it appear to lead the spout? I think it's because if you fire a water droplet to the right of the centre and then move the spout CCW, the droplet will appear to be to the right of the new direction that the spout is pointing. Assuming the pressure was enough to keep the droplet moving to get out of the "circle" before the spout caught up.


In fact, I'm going to suggest that if you fired the droplets slightly to either side, not only would it create a self-spinning sprinkler. But there's a point where the reverse-angle would undo the momentum push in direction of travel and the droplets might travel directly over the centre at the right speed.


But of course. I could be wrong. I'm happy to hear that.

There is something else to this or a way you can explain in a different way.


When shot outward to keep the same angular velocity (omega) from when the water gets ejected from the nozzle, the absolute speed has to increase. Because the speed doesn't increase the water even slows down (due to air resistance), it can't keep the same angular velocity therefore it starts trailing behind.


When the water shoots inward, this is reversed. The radius of a single droplet of water gets smaller and smaller. While the absolute speed and direction stays basically the same (minus air resistance). Therefore the angular velocity has to increases and makes it so the water is trailing ahead of the nozzle.


That being said. When you rotate this rig faster and faster. The tangental speed increases preventing the water droplets from going into a smaller radius region. Also the centrifugal force starts acting up also counteracting the force of the water to shoot inward, preventing the droplets of getting into the smaller radius regions aswel.

Here's a way to intuit this result:
If two objects are in circular motion with the same tangential velocity, but with different radii, the one with the smaller radius will have a higher angular velocity, which means it will complete the circle in less time.

Think of a helicopter blade. The end of the blade has a much higher tangential speed than the base even though both parts of the blade complete the circle in the same amount of time.
If you decrease the radius, but keep tangential velocity the same, you get a greater angular speed, which explains why the water moving inwards leads, while the water moving outwards trails.

Here’s my simple explanation for why this happens this way. Ignoring drag, we can say that any initial velocity (orthogonal to gravity) will be conserved. So, the component of velocity in the tangential (or sidewards) direction will be the same for all particles released at a given angular velocity omega. However, in order for the particles to move together in a line, omega would need to be the same for each particle. This is untrue for both cases. In the outward case, r is increasing for each particle, and v-tangential is constant. So omega decreases like 1/r with r>1. The farther out a particle is, the lower the omega, so the curve ”lags”. Similarly, for the inward case, v-tangential is constant but r is decreasing at a constant rate, so omega increases like 1/r with r<1. The closer to the center a particle is, the higher the omega at the given v-tangential, so the the curve “leads”.

Didn't read through all comments, so apologies if this is already mentioned, but first part of the video is a great demo of the difference between streaklines vs. pathlines (good ol fluid mechanics). Both gentlemen were right and just describing the two different flow visualization techniques. Pathlines are a mathematical tool and streaklines are the ones that are easiest to create in an experiment. Pathlines are the path followed by a single particle; streaklines are a "connect the dots" of all particles that passed through a common point in space (the sprinkler outlet in this case). The second part shows why hurricanes and tornados are cyclonic...yes, most certainly related to coriolis. This situation becomes very intuitive in rotating coordinates. If you set up a reference frame, which rotate with the same speed as the water source (a frame where the source does not move), you will see that everything comes out quite nicely. You will get a stationary pattern, which means the water would follow some curved lines that don`t change shape with time. The shape of that curves can be well described with the lagrangian. In particular, after writing it down you will notice the presence of Coreolis force, which is responsible for that curly shapes. Or, instead, you can just use the angular momentum conservation law and get the same answer.

How it seems slightly more intuitiv to me:
At the top of the nozzle in both cases the water has some sideways/tangential velocity in the direction of rotation.
And the only really difference between the different nozzles is that in the first experiment the radius of the water is increasing after coming out of the nozzle and in the second one its decreasing.
Because of that, the angular speed in the first experiment is decreasing (same tangential speed, but bigger radius) and becoming slower than that of the nozzle, therefore the drops seem to lag behind and the next drop out of the nozzle is placed a little "in front of it".
In the second experiment the radius is decreasing so the same sideways speed leads to more angular motion and the drops seem to overtake the nozzle which is staying at the same angular speed, releasing new drops behind the previous ones.

That's at least what I came up with during the video.

A cool effect, but arguably an easy one to figure out a priori if you spend a minute to think about it. The moment the droplet leaves the spigot, it has tangential linear velocity v₁. In the first case, it is also moving away from the axis of rotation, meaning distance from axis r is increasing, meaning its angular velocity ω = v₁/r, neglecting any dissipative effects, is steadily falling, meaning it will trace a trailing spiral in the rotating system of reference fixed on the spigot's axel. In the second case, we have a reverse of this situation: ω = v₁/r still, but r(t) decreases, so ω(t) increases (assuming constant v₁), hence the droplet's path has to look like a leading spiral in spigot's rotating system of reference.

One of the upsides of ignorance, assuming a high enough level, is a lack of bias. The less you know, the harder it is to have a preconceived notion. Conversely, the more you know, the more vulnerable you are to being blinded by preconceived notions.

As such, I try to live by a policy of "I don't know." An example being that if you were to ask me if the sun was going to rise tomorrow, I say "Probably". This forces me to acknowledge all the things I don't know and can't account for. Using words like that is a habit now, and one that I hope keeps me in check so that I don't fall into arrogance. One of humanities most common traps.

Great video, but I feel like you haven't properly identified the true root cause of the water pattern. Your video explanation, around 8:55 shows the trajectory of the water, due to the fluid flow and rotation velocity, however, your video shows that the rotational speed is exceeding the rotational speed of the source, which is the copper tubing of the sprinkler. You were on the right track when you mentioned angular momentum.
As the water moves out, the angular velocity of an individual drop has to decrease to maintain angular momentum. Hence the outward shooting water appears to spin slower/lag behind.
As water moves in, angular velocity has to increase to maintain angular momentum. Hence the inward shooting water appears to spin faster/pull ahead.

The explanation for the second sprinkler felt unfinished. It ended after saying what was similar with the first and didn't go on to explain the "non-obvious" part.
The difference is that the water is entering a smaller radius in the second one, allowing it to cover more "angular distance" and stay ahead of the spout, rather than trailing behind.

I think this is very similar to the whole can you curve a bullet experiment; just at much lower velocities. When you spin the water wheel at a constant velocity, there is not a force acting tangential to the flow of the water because the mass is not being accelerated, so it is in a rotating frame of reference. However, when the wheel is accelerated, this produces a tangential force, pushing the fluid molecules in the direction of motion. I think if a fluid with a higher viscosity was used, more of that inital departing tangential force would show up into the footage since the opposing drag force produced by the air would not shear the layers away so effectively. It blew my mind too, but then upon thinking it all makes sense. For an analogy think yourself to be standing in the center and two people running around you in two concentric circles at r and 2r distance while maintaining the same angle to you so that at any given point the father guy hides behind the closer guy when you look at them. In order to maintain the formation the guy father to you has to run fast and the guy nearer has to run slow. If the farther guy starts running at the same speed as the nearer guy, he will start lagging behind, and if the slower guy start running with the same speed of further guy, he will start moving ahead.


similarly, In the first scenario, the water is trailing because of the tangent (sidewards) component of speed (wt * r) is imparted to the water, Which in turns appear lagging because being at a further distance (r + r') centre than the tip of the pipe. So to be in the same line, it has to have more velocity as the distance from the centre has increased.
In the second scenario, The distance of water droplets from the centre is decreasing, so with the same tangential velocity of (wt * r), it is able to subtend more angle at the centre when it is at distance (r-r'). Hope it helps.

A point sitting on the equator moves faster compared to one in europe for example. So if air travels from the equator away northways it is faster than its surroundings and so there is a forward deflection to the east. The other way around: air moves from europe southways it is slower than the surface and it deflects to the west. (So on the northern hemisphere there is always a deflection to the right for objects.)


To explain it now as a physicist: This is a demonstration for the conservation of angular momentum. If you reduce/increase the radius (distance between droplet and rotational center in the video) it has to get a higher/lower angular velocity to conserve angular momentum in the rotational center.

Destin I'm only half way through so maybe you address this later on, but in the first experiment a drop of water ejected from the nozzle will have the same tangential velocity ("sidewards" as you call it) as the nozzle, but will also have an outward velocity, therefore moving it away from the center of rotation. For this reason it very clearly can not keep up with the nozzle - its angular velocity will be smaller due to a larger radius of rotation, and so it will trail behind in terms of angular position. How can you argue otherwise?

Edit: rewatching your visualization with vectors of instantaneous velocity for the water drop as it leaves the pipe, why aren't you also showing the instantaneous velocity for the tip of the pipe (what I called the nozzle)? To make matters worse you then go on to show the drop of water's velocity and position over a period of time yet ignore the fact that the pipe has also moved on and changed velocity and position. You're a smart guy so please tell me what I'm missing? Is this a matter of not choosing the same reference frame? The nozzle's is non-inertial while the drop's is inertial in the plane perpendicular to gravity.

Edit2: Watched the whole thing now and this is the exact reason why you should expect the drop of water to "trail forward" relative to the nozzle in the second experiment: same tangential velocity as the nozzle but this time a shorter distance from the center of rotation, or in other words a smaller radius, resulting in higher angular velocity.

I think the confusion here is indeed a result of the nozzle's reference frame being non-inertial. I also suspect it has something to do with the coriolis force on the individual water droplets (in the rotating reference frame of the nozzle) and the fact that it's difficult to follow the trajectory of a single droplet, and easier to (incorrectly) visualize the stream of water as if it were a single object (which it isn't of course).

I would like to disagree with the statement that the water "isn't actually trailing the pipe". As the water leaves the pipe the tangential (linear) velocities are matched, but because the water is a fluid there is no mechanism to maintain angular velocity (shear stiffness is insignificant) the water does in fact trail the pipe. This can be visualized by rotating the video with the sprinkler to set the pipe as the reference frame. The water INITIALLY leades the pipe in the second setup as the inward radial velocity causes the angular velocity to increase until the water particle is at its closest point to the center at which point angular velocity then decreases. When water (imagine instead of water, a bead) comes out of the pipe it has zero tangential velocity and zero angular velocity (zero angular velocity and tangential velocity in the frame of reference of the bead) and so from the bead's POV it would seem as if it comes straight out of the pipe. It is the opposite of the case where, when you swing a ball tied to a thread and you let go, it has tangential velocity but zero angular velocity. When we let go of the string there is nothing preventing the ball moving sideways. On the other hand the walls of the pipe stop the bead (or in this case water) and zero their tangential velocity. So the force vector with respect to the water's frame of reference at the instant it leaves the pipe is along the length of the *pipe*. And it goes straight out. And so when the pipes spin the water seems to trail behind and spiral in the direction opposite to the rotation.

So when the water leaves the nozzle, it has a tangential velocity equal to that of the nozzle plus a radial velocity. In the first experiment, the radial velocity pushed the jet of water further away from the centre. This meant that the same tangential velocity was producing less angular velocity than the nozzle, so the jet was lagging behind the nozzle. In the second experiment the radial velocity was pushing the jet towards the centre so the same tangential velocity was producing more angular velocity than the nozzle, and the jet was leading the nozzle.

This is a good case for going to a rotating frame of reference. The snapshot looks identical whether you take it in inertial frame of reference or a rotating one by definition. And in a rotating frame of reference, you don't have to think about what the trajectory looks like due to the fact that the source moved. You just have a pipe, water is coming out of it, and there are Coriolis and centrifugal forces acting on it. Fluid that's moving towards the center is bent by Coriolis forces forward. Fluid that moves away is bent back. So naturally, when stream starts pointing towards the center it bends forward along motion first, until it turns around due to centrifugal force, and then it starts bending back. All trivially true in rotating frame of reference.

I love the video and the way of thinking following each particle and saying it moves in a straight line and all, but if you just look at it in terms of conservation of angular momentum it's very simple. As the water moves towards the center it's velocity tangent to the circle going around the center has to speed up in order to conserve angular momentum since it's defined as tangent velocity times radius to the center and the radius is decreasing. Since it's tangent (circular) velocity speeds up it goes around in a circle faster then the pipe.

its all about the size if the circle. if you have a dot moving around a circle at a set speed the time it takes to get all the way around the circle depends on the circles diameter, it takes more time for said drop to traverse a bigger circle which is why they "trail" the first one, from the moment they leave the nozzle they are moving out and away from the path of the nozzle and thus are on an increasingly large circle and thus take more time to traverse the same 360 degrees, an the second test the drops are being pushed inward until the centrifugal force from their rotation overcomes there inward speed and forces them back out onto progressively larger and larger orbits until they reach a point where their relative speed is the same as the drops being flung by test 1 then they start to trail,

I would be interested in seeing the second set up on a wider angled view. Since the tangential velocity is assumed to be the same from the pipe and the water as it leaves. The pipe has zero radial velocity, but the water has an inward component. This inward component effectively decreases the radius of which the water is traveling (with the same tangential velocity the inward water will be able to travel around the 'circle' defined by the effective radius faster than if the water is shot outward. So I would think the snapshot within some radius it would appear to be advancing, but this tangential velocity becomes more and more radial as it gets further away from the center. Thus bringing us to the first set up, where the water would lag.

I would presume that this critical radius (of advanced to lagged stream) would be less than that of the water's exit radius defined by the pipe.

This leads oh-so-nicely into the classic Richard Feynman experiment (although I’m not sure he ever actually performed it as opposed to theorising about what would happen), but it’s the one he talks about in “Surely You’re Joking Mr Feynman”: if you had a rotational sprinkler like yours, but with a bend in each of the arms e.g. like a swastika, then you turn the sprinkler on, it’s reasonably clear that the water will push against the bend AND it will also be shooting out the end of each tube, which is running tangential, and both of these factors will cause it to rotate in the same direction. However, what would happen if you reversed the flow of water, say for example if you rigged the sprinkler to run *under water*, and to not shoot water from the bent poles but to suck water into it. In that case, the water is still pushing against the elbow in the same direction as before, indicating that we might see rotation in the same direction...but now the other force is reversed because the end of each tube is pulling water towards it, which indicates rotation in the other direction. Which force will win, ie which direction will the sprinkler turn? Will they cancel each other out? Are there different effects at different speeds?  I’d love to see you guys do this experiment. cheers, Ian McIntosh

when i "exit" an aeroplane by the side window - i mean door - i still have the same velocity as the plane but i immediately start experiencing drag. so while i continue (typically at ~ 170 kmph - americans do your own conversion - at the beginning - rapidly dropping from then on) horizontally towards the same direction, i trail the plane. ... If the plane was now circling i exited towards the center of the circle, and someone exited after me, i would see him curving away from me .

My simplistic take on what happens: the jet of water is made up of a number of 'particles'. Each 'particle' of water must, as you say be travelling in a straight line - once it leaves the nozzle there is no other force acting on it (ignoring gravity, friction etc) so it will (by Newton's 1st law) continue in that original direction, but as each 'particle' leaves the nozzle the nozzle has moved so they are all moving in a slightly different direction relative to one another. The jet of water, being made up of these 'particles', will, therefore, have a curved shape.

I might be wrong on this, but is this a result of conservation of angular momentum?
In the first example when we had the streams pointing outward, to conserve angular momentum of the particles (or water drops), the tangential (sideways) velocity should decrease as the radius (distance from the center) increases. Therefore, we see a trailing stream since the farther the stream is from the spout, the slower it is moving sideways.

In the second example when we had the streams pointing inward, to conserve angular momentum of the particles (or water drops), the tangential (sideways) velocity should increase as the radius (distance from the center) decreases. Therefore, we see a leading stream since the farther the stream is from the spout, the faster it is moving sideways.

I have paused the video, and am making this comment at 6:49, before they test the inward jets.

So on the outward jets, angular vs. linear velocity. As a particle travels through the copper tube, it has a fixed angular velocity thanks to the walls of the tube pushing it forward. Once it leaves the tube, it has a fixed linear velocity, and can no longer accelerate. The velocity vector at this moment is, as the diagram showed, "forward" from the tube, however since the particle is traveling outwards, the fixed linear tangential velocity corresponds to a decreasing angular velocity, causing the particle to lag behind the end of the tube which it exited, even though its velocity at the moment of exit was "forward."

With the inward facing jets, I'll use the same assumption. The particle exits the tube with a fixed linear velocity, but now it's traveling inwards, where a fixed linear tangential velocity corresponds to an increasing angular velocity, meaning the water will appear to lead the ends of the tube.

I think the most intuitive way to think about it is just viewing a single spout tip and the direction it's facing. Say one is pointing West, then as it spins, it starts pointing North. The water stream still lags behind, curving from West back to the spout pointing North. While the x-y position of the spout does move, it's the direction it's pointing that dominates the effect. Kind of like moving a camera a foot to the right but rotating it 60 degrees to the left: rotation will dominate and the picture would overall move left. So here, each individual spout is rotating the direction it points counter-clockwise, and indeed each spout's stream is lagging behind that counter-clockwise rotation, as our intuition would expect. It's just that the easy-to-see-but-largely-irrelevant positional changes to each spout makes the dominating rotational changes hard to see.

A good way to think about the reason the water "curves" ahead or behind the way it does is to reframe the problem.

Suppose, instead of a spinning sprinkler thing, we have a firetruck driving along, spraying water out from its hose in a sideways direction 90 degrees from the direction the truck is driving. If the fire truck were to drive around in a circle, then it's exactly like the sprinkler. Just imagine the truck driving along where one of the nozzles on the spinning sprinkler is.

But since this is a truck, we should consider what happens if it were to drive in a straight line. In this case, the water coming out the hose is going fowards at the same speed as the truck, so the spray just looks like it's going in a straight line sideways out of the truck, at a perfect 90 degree angle (assuming atmospheric drag doesn't slow it down anyway).

Now, suppose the truck turns in the opposite direction from the side the water is spraying out of. It is turning away from the spray, and so the truck eventually turns far enough that some of the water is behind it. This is like the case where the nozzle on the spinny sprinkler is pointing outwards.

What if the truck turns in the same direction as the water is spraying from? It is then turning toward the spray, and so the truck eventually turns enough that some of the water is in front of it. This is like the case with the inward pointing nozzle.

The important thing is that the water goes in a straight line. It is the truck (or sprinkler) that is doing all the turning!

I think one of the common thing people assume in their mind when they see this is that each water particle would follow the stream of water before it, and that the water stream is the trajectory a water particle follows. But that is not the case. As the rig spins around, the initial position at which each water particle exits the tube is constantly changing, in another word, the stream of water that we see is not originated from the location of the nozzle that we see. Instead, the water particles that form the most of that stream originated from behind the current position of the nozzle.

Its intriguing that though individual particles motion is rectilinear(ignoring z motion), the water streams appear to be spirals.
Turns out that the locus of particles do indeed form spirals. The trajectory follows

x=(R + t v) Cos[wt -theta0] + Rtw Sin[wt-theta0]

y=Rtw Cos[wt- theta0] - (R + t v) Sin[wt- theta0]
where
v is radial velocity (+ve for outwards flow)
w the angular velocity
R the nozzle length
theta0 the initial angle the nozzle tube makes with the x axis when viewed from above.
t time

The first case test: as soon as water droplet leaves the nozzle it becomes a projectile and no longer receives any further energy, so the nozzle tangential velocity will always be higher than the droplet tangential velocity. Now imagine if you some how manage to add more energy to the water droplet (make it propelled and not as a projectile), its tangential velocity will always be higher than the nozzle tangential velocity, no matter how slow the nozzle goes. This exactly what happened in the second test where you added vertical pipe that adds energy to water without changing the tangential velocity.

The whole reason this was even a debate is because you forgot that phase and phase angle were a thing.


This problem becomes ridiculously easy to understand from your own angular/directional frame of particle movement, if you take into account the distance of the particle from the tip increases how far out of time it is with the tip of the nozzle.


Any kid with a hose can tell you that it takes a second for the water to get where you aim the hose, because the old water is still travelling to where it was going when it was freed from its prison of fluid dynamics and instead is free to act according to the laws of gravity and motion.


You were almost right though, because you said that it would change with rotational speed, and you were right. There comes a speed when it looks as if the water is travelling backwards, because the tip of the nozzle is moving so fast that it gets to the other side of the circle before the ejected water does, and suddenly instead of going straight, the water looks like it is going backwards. You were right, because you initially said it would stop and turn around and go backwards, away from the center, because yes, with the addition of some rotational velocity, it goes outwards rather than inwards, and with some time delay, the tip moves far enough it gives the illusion of a curved stream.


The whole reason the simple tube experiment is simple arcs made from straight lines, is because the further from the tip, the further out of phase the water gets, until eventually at some distance 2r it is 1 rotation behind the tip out of phase. This is why the inwards jets look weird, because theyre going forwards in phase instead of backwards, because theyre getting closer to the center, and actually exit the circle before the tip of the nozzle gets there.


At some speed, the rotational velocity will outpace the ejected velocity, and it will immediately just be flung away and smacked by the nozzle. Hypothetically, at some speed ridiculously high, it would reverse the flow, because the tip of the nozzle would actually move ahead of where the water would be going, because the water is launched from slightly closer to the center than the edge of the tube.

If you sweep a laser beam across the moon from Earth, the dot you trace out on the surface of the moon will move across the lunar surface faster than light. Nothing in nature can travel faster than light, so in order to understand that this happens you have to understand that the dot is a made up social construct. In reality none of the photons that make up the laser beam have anything to do with each other. The laser is continuously making new dots, not moving one around. The notion that the dot you see in one place is the same one that you see anywhere else is just your brain making things up.

They should have had pulses of colored water in the stream, so they could track the actual motion better, as opposed to apparent motion (like they said for simpler example, it will in a snapshot look as if the water trails behind, spiraling opposite direction. Simply because that is the way the continuous... "graph" looks like). I would say destin is correct as he describes its actual motion (the water has tangential motion and radial motion, the radial motion making water fly outwards over time, while the tangential motion moved further away, making it move less of the circumference each tick than the spout. Not to mention it doesn't remain tangential as there is no anti-radial acceleration, so it can't create kepler orbits), while mould were thinking of how the curve you can draw from the spout as you follow the older water curves backwards.

edit: later in the video now, and they seem to bring this point up. And it is even more evident in the second device, as it is shooting water inwards: You see that as the radius decreases, the "angular velocity" increases (moving tangentially with same speed as it left, it traverses a large portion of the circumference, as it moves same distance per tick, but circle is smaller). You also see what I mentioned about how a lack of anti-radial accerelation makes what was a tangential velocity quickly turn into something that is not tangential (compared to the portion of the circle a line drawn from the colored droplet to the circles center intersects with), meaning there are no kepler orbits. Which is why you see the droplet move in a straight line, and the apparent motion of the stream looks like it curves into a u-turn.


edit2: finished video now, this whole video reminds me of the xkcd comic about centrifugal forces. Mould isn't _right_, but he isn't wrong either. He is seeing an apparent motion by looking at the rotating spout as stationary and motion as the curve fitted to the "datapoints". Which was why he was so adamant to using snapshots despite lugging out a slo-mo camera that would let them track droplets (why didn't you take the effort to make it a laminar flow btw? I am disappointed, it is this channel and yet there was no laminar flow!), in a snapshot the spout (and droplets) are stationary, and the only way to infer motion is by looking at the "graph" made by water.

Great demonstration of the Coriolis effect.

so when the jet is pointed inwards, the sidewards velocity of the water (tangential component) is the same as the nozzle, and this is greater than the sidewards velocity of the inner portions of the pipe that it passes. this is why it "leads" the pipe. when the stream points outwards, the sidewards velocity of the stream remains the same, but "lags" because this is slower than a hypothetical pipe moving at the same rpm further from center. this is a demonstration of conservation of angular momentum. you can also note that the water droplets that shoot inwards, after they pass close to the center of rotation and fly outward again, start lagging the pipe rotation when they are further from the center. the curve of the stream (pause at 8:59) is in the same counter clockwise direction as the outward stream, but the inward momentum has advanced the phase angle of this curve by 90 degrees.

The 'curve' comes from making a line on a set of points, just like any line in basic mathematics. When you look at an individual cluster of particles, yes they move outwards radially, but when you look at the stream, or line, of water, it curves.
Now on the second machine, intuition would tell you that the curves would be inverted, as one component of the vector has been inverted.
The tangential never changes, but the direction of the radial does; the first machine has any values greater than X on the radial line, the second has any values less than X on the radial line. To put this in 'Alabamian' terms, the sideward force never changes, but the first machine goes outward while the second goes inward.

Maybe it's obvious in hindsight, but doesn't the water behave like orbital mechanics? Going outwards, the tangential velocity lags that needed for the jet to stay normal to the orbit, so the jet spirals behind the rotation. Going inwards, the opposite is true, so the jet spirals ahead of the rotation. This is exactly like orbital mechanics, where you have to descend to a tighter orbit to go faster, and ascend to go slower, and was also counter to intuition when we first started flying in space.

Feels like you forgot to mention why the water travels ”ahead” when spraying inwards and ”behind” when spraying outward.

The answer is simple geometry, when spraying inward the ”radius” decreases so the droplets travel faster than the shaft (since they have the tangential velocity at the tip).
When spraying outward the ”radius” increases and the droplets travel slower than the imaginary extension of the pipes.

Sure, just saying ”look at the resultant of velocities and remember that unless acted on by a force everything travels straight” explains the phenomena, but I feel like the simple geometry aspect explains the ”optical illusion” which really isn’t an illusion, the water is really shooting out in front and lagging behind the pipes, if you were to place something there (in the same rotational reference frame) it would become wet, so not really an ”illusion”.
If the second one spun faster it would have trailed, but it never spun fast enough to. It's just that the pressure of the water coming out of the pipe was stronger than the velocity from spinning.

There's actually a deeper reason why it curves forward. If you trace the path of an individual droplet, it has to exit the circle at some point (and by circle I mean the circular path of the spouts). The question is, at the point where it exits, does it get there before the spout, or aftee? If before, the stream will look like it's curving forward. If it's after the spout, the stream will look like it's trailing backward. So Destin actually had good intuition to guess that at a certain speeds it curves backward, and at certain speeds it curves forward.

notice that the droplet travels in a straight line toward the circular boundary, while the spouts have to travel along the circumference. So the droplets have a shorter distance to move. In addition, the speed of the droplet is the speed of the spout PLUS the speed of the water flow, so it's moving faster than the spout. So not only does the droplet have a shorter distance to cover, it moves faster. It MUST reach it's exit point on the circular boundary before the spout gets there. So that's why the stream always curves forward, no matter the speed

Nice video, though I think talking only about the straight direction of water droplets is half the problem and the source of the illusion could have been articulated a little better.

In the first case, the water is going outwards and with the maximal „sidewards“ velocity provided/allowed by the pipe: v_max =w * L ;
w - angular velocity
L - length of the pipe
v_max - maximal sidewards velocity.
After leaving the pipe, the water continues to move outwards from the pipe and sidewards with the maximal velocity v_max. Now, since nothing is acting on the water as the water is going outwards its sidewards velocity cannot increase. The velocity would have to increase for the water to keep up (or lead) with the pipe according to the same v=w* (L+ s), but that is not the case and the water begins trailing the pipe (s - any additional distance once out of the pipe).

In the second case, the water again leaves with the maximal „sidewards velocity“ provided by the pipe, but this time inwards. And this inwards part is where the illusion is coming from. The end of the pipe is the fastest moving part of the pipe, while as we go inwards, the pipe moves slower and slower. Since the water leaves with sidewards velocity v_max and is going inwards, it moves faster than any other part of the pipe and, hence, leads the pipe. The closer the water is to the center, the faster is the water when compared to the pipe and the greater is the water's deviation from the pipe.
Another way to solve this is to note  that having an angular velocity at some radius means having a slower or faster angular velocity at larger or smaller radii.

It wasn't exactly explained in this video, so I'm just going to clarify here:
The reason it looks like it curves forward on the inward spouts but backwards on the outward spouts is because on the inward spouts, the water is going inward, which means that the same linear lateral (or in Destin's words "sidewards") velocity corresponds to a higher rotational velocity. This is because rotational velocity is linear lateral velocity divided by radius and as it heads inward, the linear lateral velocity doesn't change (much) but the radius rapidly decreases. This gives an appearance of curving ahead.
On the outward spouts, however, the opposite happens. The lateral velocity doesn't change, but the r adius increases, which corresponds to a decreasing rotational velocity and the appearance of lagging behind.

In other news, the message at the end about being very certain in even incorrect theories really hits home with me, though for me I don't really interact with anyone on an equal level in physics and whatever (either the other person is basically clueless and asking me to explain something or I'm asking a physicist to explain to me something I don't get) so it mostly applies to things outside of STEM (not to mention that I'm rarely wrong xP).

@Destin, the problem is it is all about reference frames (co-ordinate systems). 1. on the first problem the water is moving with a steady tangential velocity and as the radius grows it moves slower than if you extended the radius of the spout, therefore your mind gives you the reference that it is moving slower and "backwards". your mind has given a reference to the spout as it cannot track an individual droplet. 2. when the water is pointing towards the center the opposite is true. now the tangential velocity is greater than the tangential velocity of the perceived radius and so the water "leads" the spout. like you said optical illusions but also a good lesson in reference co-ordinate systems.


if you take an absolute reference the droplets follow a straight path, if you take a moving reference it is either a leading or lagging curve that is generated. Something the phantom makes more obvious but can be used more in educational settings when discussing differing co-ordinate systems. Neither is wrong but they do lead to different views of the same truth.

My guess before watching the first part:

Switch into a rotating reference frame with the water spinner. Let's say the spinner is spinning clockwise in the xy plane, meaning the angular velocity is directed in the -z direction. As water travels in the +y direction, it will experience a Coriolis force and be deflected in the -x direction (so it'll be Steve's prediction)


Perhaps a way of thinking about this in the inertial reference frame is this: What Destin said about it having a "sideways velocity" is right, however having the same tangential velocity does not mean having the same angular velocity. The farther out the water goes, the more distance it has to travel to keep up with the spinner, but since they have the same tangential speed, it's going to be hard to catch up to it.

The further out from a circle you go, the further and faster you have to go to keep up with the things closer to the center to stay in a straight line.   That's why it trails.  When the water is going the speed of the outer edge but exiting into to the center, it makes sense that it gets ahead of the movement.  It's angular velocity is higher than the angular velocity of the wire closer to the center.  And it stays higher until air friction slows it down.

In high school physics, once an object is in motion, it stays in motion until another force acts on it. Had this been a ball on the end of a string, the moment the string is cut, the straight line tangent of it's vector is it's path. Our brains and eyes combine the stream together to make it appear as it lags behind speed of rotation of nozzles. The water is always going strsight-line forward (from the point it was set free) while being pulled to the Earth simultaneously. It is the trailing water stream that followed that forms the curved arcs we view as an optical illusion.

The key point that made it click for me is this: The magnitude of tangential component of the velocity of the water coming out of the tube is proportional to the radius at the point it exits. Now imagine a line extending outward. The tangential component of a point out there moving on that line would be greater than the speed of the water shooting outward so the water seems to "lag behind".

Contrast this to shooting water inwards. In that case a point on the line has a smaller tangential component than for the water, so the water seems to "dart ahead".

Everyone needs to learn this:
When presented with a problem, oftentimes, I get pretty headstrong because life experience makes me think I know all the answers and when that happens, in my heart I am less likely to hear the other person. At times during this experiment, Steve and I were communicating the exact same physical truths from two different perspectives. And because we weren’t saying it exactly the same way I misinterpreted that to mean that one of us had to be wrong. As I look back at this footage it was obvious to me that Steve clearly understood my perspective but I can’t say I took the time to do the same for him. Because of that when I was really wrong and he was trying to explain it to me I was already shut down. I couldn’t see it. I just looked like an idiot. Here’s the takeaway for me: when I disagree with someone or at least when I think I disagree with someone, it is imperative that I stop, listen, and I don’t move on until I completely understand the other person’s perspective because it’s possible you’ll find that you don’t actually disagree. - Destin

I'll bet if you had started with a spinning disk (think record on a record player) and visualized rolling a ball from the edge (initially moving at edge speed) straight toward the middle, you'd have immediately recognized this as a demonstration of the Coriolis effect. It's less obvious with the water because you have no solid frame of reference. It's just the ball (water particle) floating through the air.
If we look at the northern hemisphere of the earth as the spinning disk. Put a low pressure system in the middle latitudes and watch what happens as a large air mass is pulled from the south (closer to the edge) to the north (closer to the middle). The air mass is carried along with the east to west velocity of the spinning earth, but as it moves northward the earth rotates underneath in a counterclockwise direction and the path of the air mass appears to bend to the right (to the east). Air moving from north to south also trying to follow a straight line has the earth rotate under it, and like your first water experiment appears to lag behind which so its own path also bends to the right (to the west). This causes counterclockwise rotation of the winds around the low pressure area in the northern hemisphere, and clockwise around low pressure areas in the south.

It is kinda unintuitive, but it all makes perfect sense if you think about different velocities of particles at different distances from the rotation center. A particle released at some distance (or radius) r has a specific tangential velocity. If it moves away from the center of rotation at the time of its release, its distance from the center of velocity will increase. However, It is no longer accelerated tangentially, so it will "lag behind" the newly released particles. But if it moves towards the center of rotation, its tangential velocity is faster than the one of any given particle it encounters along the way to the center. It will look like it is leading in front of the rotation.

In terms of actually answering the question Steve asked: The question was "if you spin it and take a snapshot, what does the snapshot look like?". Which to me is asking what shape of water streams will we see in the snapshot.

To try and answer that question with velocity vectors is very difficult. You can deduce what each particle would do, but it's a lot of work to calculate where each particle will end up in order to determine the shape of the water stream.

I think It's much easier to think of it as a question of conservation of angular momentum (think of a spinning figure skater speeding up as she brings her arms inwards and slowing down as she brings them back out). If you think about it this way, then it's easier to deduce that water flowing outwards would lag behind and water flowing inwards would lead in front.

I have a theory about why the water is able to curve ahead. The water trails ahead or behind the arms based on how fast it is able to move tangentially to the center of rotation.
Lets say that the tips of the arms move tangentally relative to the center at a speed of 1. When the drops are being shot outward away from the center, they have more speed than the arms, but most of that speed is away from the center and not tangental to it. Thus the drops have a tangental speed of less than 1 and they trail behind the arms.
When the drops are being shot inwards, their direction of motion takes them closer to the center and thus more of their speed is directed tangentially, giving them a tangental speed of more than 1 and causing them to trail ahead.

This was an interesting video and the ideas can definitely be counterintuitive. I think Destin answered how all the particles moved, but there was not a solid connection to why the frames looked the way they did.

The reason Destin was "wrong" was that he didn't compare the particles position to the sprinkler. This means looking at relative velocities of particles of the sprinkler and particles of the streams of water. When you do this, Destin's predictions lead to the right answer in both cases.

For the first example, as the water leaves, it maintains the same tangential velocity, but it is moving away from the center. This moving away, means that in order to keep up with the circular motion of the pipe that it left, it would have to speed up (the outer particles of spinning disks move faster than the inner particles). Because it obviously cant speed up, it appears to lag behind.

The second example is very similar, except now, the water moves towards the center. This means that now the tangential element of the water's velocity is compared to the inner part of the sprinkler where it is slower. This creates the illusion that the water is speeding ahead of the sprinkler.

This effect at first seemed impossible but now I get it. It's because angluar velocity = transitional velocity * radius from point of rotation. So on a rigid body like the spigot, the instantaneous velocity of a particle on the spigot is moving faster on the outside than it is on the inside. and the exact moment the water leaves the spigot, it has the same velocity as the tip of the spigot. When the water is shooting outward, the velocity of the particle is maintained but it's distance from the center of the spigot increases. If we were to imagine extending the tip of the spigot along with the water, we would see that the spigot would have to be moving faster than the water. Therefore the water lags.




The converse is when the water is shooting inwards. Again we have to recognize that the velocity of the water is not changing. If we track a point on the spigot along with the water we can see that as we move inward the instantaneously velocity of a point on the spigot is decreasing. Therefore the water is moving faster and leading.


If this is confusing, another way to think about this is to consider the angular velocity of the water particle itself (which personally is easier for me), with reference to the center of the spigot. In someways it's easier to process but I think it's weird for some people to think about the angular velocity of a particle when it's not actually "rotating" about a point.

And for that question your answer is wrong because you chose to think about a single drop and speculate that the trail of the water goes the same way as the absolute velocity of that single drop. This is only valid, under the assumption that the stream of water is continuous. I think there is another way to see it that might help some people:
For a few moments after the water leaves the hose the "sideways" velocity of the water is practically parallel to the velocity of the end of the hose and vertical to the centre of rotation, because the hose hasn't turned enough and almost no time has passed.
So, when the water is propelled, again for a few moments, you can compare the 2 moving objects (the water droplet and the edge of the hose) as moving with the same "sideways" velocity in circles with the same centre.
Because of the propulsion, in the first example, the water is being pushed to moving in circles of bigger radius. Having the same "sideways" velocity but moving in a bigger circle means the angular velocity is lower(it is "turning" slower) and so the droplet lags behind.
In the second case, the droplet is forced to move in a smaller circle, so it's angular velocity is bigger and it outruns the end of the hose.

For those struggling to grasp this.
In the first example the water leaves with a tangential velocity equal to that of the nozzle and had a diagonal direction of motion however the pipe nozzle keeps moving in the tangential direction making it seem as if the water is lagging behind.

The same happens with the second example the illusion kicks in even you see it move to the center. The water leaves the nozzle with a certain tangential velocity however since it is moving closer to the center the part of the pipe close to the center has a lower tangential velocity making the water move further away from the parts of the pipe close to the center. This happens because the pipes tangential velocity is relative to the center meaning it will change and keep turning in the direction of the circle while the water's tangential velocity is fixed. This in essence makes the water faster in the direction of it's vector as the pipe turns

Nice video Destin! Gong by your explanation, the water should have two velocity components when it comes out of the nozzle , but I think it will just have one. The angular velocity that you consider, is relative to the observer on land. So, that cannot explain why the stream takes a "visually" curved path(though individual droplets only have linear velocity). Imagine sitting on top of the nozzle and observing the droplets. You will notice that relative direction of motion of each droplet (as it exits the nozzle) to its preceding droplet is opposite to the direction of motion of the nozzle. So just like how we add up the relative velocity of two objects in antithetical direction, we feel that the water is going ahead of the nozzle. In the the first case where the water was forced away from the center, the same explanation holds, just that the relative direction is positive, so we subtract the relative velocities and the water looks like it is trailing. There are no two vectors to this problem.

First of all, hats off for admitting that you were wrong and that you should improve your listening ability (I myself do too, and this was a good reminder).

Second, I think I have a better and more intuitive way of explaining the phenomena. Bear with me:

On the 1st case the water after leaving the pipe, keeps its TANGENTIAL (ahhaha 😉) velocity, but because it's shot outwards the radius of the virtual circle its traversing it's increasing and therefore its angular velocity its getting smaller & smaller (ω = v/r), and therefore it gives the impression of lagging behind the pipe's rotation.

On the 2nd case the same is true, i.e. the water keeps its tangential velocity, BUT b/c it is shot inwards , in the direction of smaller & smaller radii, its angular velocity ω it's increasing with respect to the pipe tip, giving the impression of leading the apparatus rotating motion.

Hey Destin, you were basically looking at the single droplets in the rotational noninertial reference system they are in when they leave the snout, but failed to correctly account for the coriolis force. I'm surprised none of you brought that term up during the video, because it makes predicting what is going to happen pretty easy.
You wanted to know how the snapshots look, a rather difficult question from the reference system of the ground. However, its easy to answer from the rotating reference system. The water will tries to go straight out of the snout but then is affected by coriolis force and bend to the left or right depending on the direction of rotation. Now the key thing is: The snapshot will look the same in both reference systems, because the picture basically freezes the motion. Or to look at it in a different way: for photons the speeds we are observing here are basically a standstill.

Hey Destin, I think that the element of this device you don't get the point across well in this video is the reason why it curves ahead or behind, you only explain the water is actually moving in straight lines. I believe as Steve would explain it, the droplet of water has a fixed velocity as it leaves the nozzle, as you explain. As a rotating object moves away from the center of rotation, it requires a higher velocity to move the same angular distance. Because the velocity is fixed when leaving the nozzle, as a droplet moves away from the center of rotation, it has less velocity than a point at that radius on the line drawn by the nozzle, so it falls behind, and so the group of all the water droplets creates a curve falling behind the nozzle. Likewise, in the inward pointing device, as a droplet moves inward toward the center of rotation, it maintains its velocity, which moving inward is faster than a point at that radius on the nozzle, so it moves ahead of it, with the group of all points creating an arc curving ahead of the nozzle.

Ok so I have a few things to say :
So throughout the video, you have these two different perspectives and it's hard to figure out which one is right. Turns out they both are ! But while Destin says one of them is sort of an "optical illusion", I'll try to convince you that they both make perfect physical sense.
So the first perspective where you draw a circle around a droplet and follow it in a straight line corresponds to an inertial reference frame, while looking at the snapshot and the curve the water is creating corresponds to a rotating, non-galilean reference frame. To visualise this better, imagine the camera rotated exactly in sync with the device. In this kind of reference frame, you see an actual force appearing, called the Coriolis force, which curves the trajectory of moving objects in a circle. The way it works is if an object is moving away from the axis of rotation, its trajectory will be curved in the opposite direction of the rotation (it trails behind), and if it moves inwards the opposite happens (it gets ahead of the rotation). Now the actual math here involves a cross product between the vector representing the angular velocity of the system and the velocity of the water particle, but a simpler way of undertanding this phenomenon is within the inertial frame : v=wr (where w is angular speed), so this means that while the actual speed of a particle is conserved, if the radius increases, its angular speed decreases and vice-versa.
My point here is that while this isn't magic or anything, and it can all be explained in the inertial frame, the rotating frame is a valid, if not galilean, point of view and there's an actual force, if not a causal one (that is to say that its only cause is the rotation itself and the movement of the object and not an action) at play here.

One way to describe this phenomena that may be more intuitive is that we have to remember that when turning, the velocity of the outer most point is faster than they inner most point.

So think of it this way, in the pointing outward example, the water is going at at a particular velocity after leaving the spout and is no longer connected to and influenced by the mechanical motion of the spin, so it doesn’t have a fast enough velocity to keep in line with the pipes as it travels farther from the center of rotation and so we see a lag.

Now reverse the direction where the water is shooting inward, now the velocity of the water is moving faster than the velocity needed to keep in line with the pipes so the water shoots ahead of them since the velocity of the inner section of pipe is slower than where the water was initially released.

Destin! There are already words in fluid mechanics that describe the basic disagreement you're having!

A "streamline" is a line describing the overall flow of motion in a fluid, but only at one point in time. If nothing else changes, a fluid particle that starts on a streamline travels along it over time.

A "streakline" is what you get when you inject ink into water or smoke into air: a snapshot of particles that passed that point some time in the past were at the moment the snapshot is taken.

A "Pathline" is the path taken by a single particle in the fluid over time.

None of these are the same, though the differences can be subtle! You were talking about pathlines while Steve was talking about something like streaklines, though I'm not sure water in air stricly meets the definition.

Reference frames. You guys were both speaking truth but from different reference frames.

FIRST SPRINKLER (SPOUTS POINTING OUT)

Destin, you're reference frame was the ground. Therefore, you were looking at how the water moved relative to the ground. In which case, the water droplets were moving forward and away from the center do to their kinetic energy.

Steve, your reference frame was the spinning sprinkler. Therefore, you were looking at how the water moved relative to the spinning sprinkler. In which case, the water droplets were lagging behind the sprinkler because the sprinkler was outrunning them and they were slowing down do to drag.

SECOND SPRINKLER (SPOUTS POINTING IN)

Destin, you see the water droplets doing the exact same thing as the first sprinkler. Which, from your ground reference frame, they are.

However, if you look at them from Steve's reference frame (the sprinkler) then you'll see something very interesting.
Put simply, the water droplets appear to out run the sprinkler.
This is do to the water droplets gaining angular momentum because they're being propelled toward the center of rotation.

BIG REVEAL
This actually causes the droplets to physically out run the sprinkler. This isn't an optical allusion if you use the sprinklers as your reference frame.

This is the same principle as pulling your arms in while you're spinning. As your arms approach the center of rotation, they increase angular velocity (And since your arms are connected to your body, they speed your body's rotation as well)

P.S. This effect works in reverse as well. That's another reason why the droplets were slowing down and lagging behind in the first sprinkler.

So... The first example is indeed a linguistic problem, though you could also call it a frame of reference problem. (eg. it's a relativity problem, in some sense. - after all, Relativity states there is no absolute frame of reference in the universe, only relative ones.)

Relative to where a drop of water was launched from (in an external frame of reference - eg. relative to the ground) the water moves in a straight line, along the vector that is the sum of the force imparted by the rotation and the water pressure.

Now, in a rotating frame of reference however (one that follows the motion of the rotating pipes), the water particles lag behind the motion of the pipes, which means they are moving away from the pipes in a circular motion that lags behind them...

Both are correct, but they depend on your frame of reference...

Also that second result was pretty weird to watch.

But in hindsight it makes perfect sense when you consider some other examples that rely on similar principles...

For instance, the only known method to produce 'artificial gravity' relies on being on the inside of a rotating cylinder... Well, anyway. A bit too tired to really think that through... But yeah...

I think it's a little bit easier if you think of it in terms of conservation of angular momentum. When water shoots out of the spout in the outwards direction, since the radius of rotation is increasing, the angular velocity of the water has to decrease. And it's the exact opposite the other way around.
There's a parallel here with Destin's explanation: changing the radius of rotation of the water, let's say incresing it (shooting outwards), means that the water would have to travel more space at a time to keep up with the spout's rpm, which couldn't happen since the linear velocity of the water is going to remain constant. And again it's the exact opposite the other way around.

I agree that the premiere feature is useless and annoying, but I feel like the amount of dislikes is a bit too harsh of a reaction for that alone.

It's just a 180 degree rotation. In the traditional apparatus, your velocity vector parallel to your piping sends water on am ever increasing radius. So it's tangential velocity makes a larger "circle" that "trails" behind. The new apparatus shortens the radius meaning the spout has to travel farther. It can increase speed to keep up. Think of closing a gate and walking a straight line to the post you secure it to for a more intuitive understanding. Eventually it could potentially pass through the stream and make a curlicue. That'd be an interesting question. to answer... Does the increase in angular velocity keep the water from ever "boomeranging" back to the spout?

Yeah, agree with the comments Destin. Although the Premiere feature notifies subscribers of the video and builds “hype”, it makes it seem like the video is uploaded and published, only to disappoint people with a long timer. Because of this, many of the people who clicked on the video before it’s actual release thinking it was uploaded will then click away, only to never get the notification again and thus actually never watch it when it is playable. The video often gets less views in the end and does not get as much interaction overall as when a video is released ready to play. Just a thought! Love your videos man, but not sure about Premier is the way to go. Maybe announce the video in a Community Post or YouTube Story? That way, we’ll still get the notification when the video is actually published for us to play!
